history.content:
EE16A is not purely a linear algebra course. Unless you have prior circuits knowledge, it'll be quite hard to teach. Moreover, with 16A being such a popular course, I don't think they'd take you as part of the teaching staff without having taken the class.

To answer your second question, no. It is a hard requirement without any alternative. See https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-lowerdiv.

*** To respond to the above statement, 16A is not a hard requirement for L&S CS. Math 54 is an alternative. Reading the linked page shows that the combination of Math 54 and EE16B will satisfy the 16AB requirement for students both before and after Fall 2017.

^^to the above person. While you're right that its not a hard requirement, taking 16B without taking 16A/47D is strongly not advised.

children.subject: Wouldn't simply taking the class be easier/less time consuming than teaching it?

history.content: I have heard of a student who instead of taking EE16A will be able to fulfill the requirement (L&S) by teaching the course instead. I have extensive experience with linear algebra, similar to this student, and I was wondering how I could do the same. Do the department guidelines strictly require EE16A to be taken in order to graduate?
history.subject: Alternatives to EE16A
